cutoff_ranges.recommendations: Your sodium level is low. A repeat blood test is recommended. If the level is persistently low, further tests may be required to rule out metabolic and kidney disorders. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your sodium level is raised. This may be due to dehydration, and high intake of salty food. A repeat blood test is recommended. If the level is persistently raised, further tests may be required to rule out metabolic and kidney disorders. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your potassium level is low. You are encouraged to increase your intake of potassium-rich food such as bananas, dark green leafy vegetables, mushrooms, and yoghurt. A repeat blood test is recommended. If the level is persistently low, further tests will be required to rule out metabolic and kidney disorders. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your potassium level is borderline raised. You are encouraged to avoid potassium-rich food such as bananas, potatoes, mushrooms, and yoghurt. A repeat blood test is recommended. If the level is persistently raised, further tests will be required to rule out metabolic and kidney disorders. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.
Your potassium level is raised. This may be due to underlying metabolic and kidney disorders. A repeat blood test and treatment are recommended. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

special_remarks.potassium_remarks: Your potassium level is too high, and thus it is not recordable. This may be due to underlying metabolic and kidney disorders. A repeat blood test and treatment are recommended. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

cutoff_ranges.recommendations: Your chloride level is low. Chloride works together with sodium, potassium, and bicarbonate to help balance acids and bases in your body. Low levels of chloride may be associated with heart failure, lung disease, and Addison's disease. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your chloride level is raised. Chloride works together with sodium, potassium, and bicarbonate to help balance acids and bases in your body. High levels of chloride may be associated with dehydration, Cushing's syndrome, and kidney disease. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your bicarbonate level is low. Bicarbonate works together with sodium, potassium, and chloride to help balance acids and bases in your body. Low levels of bicarbonate may be associated with Addison's disease, lung disease, and kidney disease. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your bicarbonate level is raised. Bicarbonate works together with sodium, potassium, and chloride to help balance acids and bases in your body. High levels of bicarbonate may be associated with dehydration, Cushing's syndrome, and lung disease. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your urea level is low. Urea is naturally produced when the liver breaks down protein and is removed from the body in the urine. Low levels of urea may be associated with overhydration. It is recommended that you reduce your fluid intake.

Your urea level is raised. Urea is naturally produced when the liver breaks down protein and is removed from the body in the urine. High levels of urea may be associated with dehydration, a high protein diet after prolonged fasting, and certain kidney diseases. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your creatinine level is low. Creatinine is produced as a by-product of muscle function and is excreted by the kidneys. Decreased levels of creatinine may be associated with muscle diseases and kidney diseases. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your creatinine level is raised. Creatinine is produced as a by-product of muscle function and is excreted by the kidneys. High levels of creatinine may be associated with renal impairment. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your creatinine level is low. Creatinine is produced as a by-product of muscle function and is excreted by the kidneys. Decreased levels of creatinine may be associated with muscle diseases and kidney diseases. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your creatinine level is raised. Creatinine is produced as a by-product of muscle function and is excreted by the kidneys. High levels of creatinine may be associated with renal impairment. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.

Your eGFR reading is low, and is suggestive of severe chronic renal disease. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice. Note: The eGFR is estimated using a IDMS traceable creatinine Jaffe, method based on CKD-EPI equation, it has not been validated in children (age < 18 years), pregnant women, or in some racial or ethnic subgroups, such as Hispanics.

Your eGFR reading is low, and is suggestive of chronic renal disease. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice. Note: The eGFR is estimated using a IDMS traceable creatinine Jaffe, method based on CKD-EPI equation, it has not been validated in children (age < 18 years), pregnant women, or in some racial or ethnic subgroups, such as Hispanics.

An eGFR 60-89 ml/min/1.73m2 indicates a possibility of mildly reduced kidney function. You are advised to repeat eGFR if there is no protein in your urine test. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice. Note: The eGFR is estimated using a IDMS traceable creatinine Jaffe, method based on CKD-EPI equation, it has not been validated in children (age < 18 years), pregnant women, or in some racial or ethnic subgroups, such as Hispanics.
Your urine albumin creatinine ratio suggests microalbuminuria. This may be associated with kidney impairment. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.
Your urine albumin creatinine ratio suggests macroalbuminuria. This may be associated with kidney impairment. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.
Your urine albumin creatinine ratio suggests microalbuminuria. This may be associated with kidney impairment. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.
Your urine albumin creatinine ratio suggests macroalbuminuria. This may be associated with kidney impairment. Please consult our doctor for further medical advice.
